data.body: I just upgraded to VS Code 0.10.8 and I see that the debug console is now at the bottom of the window. I can see how some people might prefer this, but I actually preferred having it on the right side. The position (right/bottom) should be configurable in settings.

- In response to issue #1238.
- Fixed regular expression for Markdown headers, testing across a variety of my repositories that are Markdown heavy without issues, but additional testing is probably warranted.

data.title: Page after installation is a 404 not found
Please support source maps with inlined source code
data.body:
I have patiently tried to use Babel to produce JavaScript source maps that works with VSCode. 

The latest published version of `gulp-sourcemaps` (1.6.0) doesn't have the ability to produce a correct relateive path from the compiled code to the source file in the `sources` array when your output is in a tree parallel to your source. This made it impossible to use gulp+babel to build maps that worked with VS Code, since it doesn't support inline source code. [So I forked it and fixed it.](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/936)

All was well for a while, but now I've come back to the project again, and they no longer work. But I have no idea why - there's no diagnostic about why the source map isn't shown. This is probably my own fault, since I had a feature request to [show native code if source map isn't available](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-node-debug/issues/23). Which is great!! Unless you were expecting a source map and didn't get one. Now you just don't see a source map and don't see an error. :(

I have pored over my target files & the `sources` look exactly right. Nothing has changed since I got this working a couple months ago. I've tried messing with `outDir`, I just see nothing wrong. So I am not sure if this is a new bug in vscode, or something I just can't see that I accidentally broke since the last time it worked.

I feel like trying to get nodejs + babel source maps working reliably in VS Code has become a hobby akin to using a metal detector to find gold on a beach. I want it to work so badly, because the debugging experience is so awesome compared to anything else, but I just can't seem to make it work reliably no matter how hard I try.

I think all this would go away if VSCode just supported embedded source code. There's be nothing to get lost, no relative paths to worry about, no concerns about distribution vs. source code heirarchy. It would just work, the way it always does in chrome.

What are the chances this can become a reality?

data.body:
I have tried every solution I could find but I cannot get it to work. I am currently stuck with this error:

```
initialize: can't create debug session for adapter 'mono'
```

Following is contents of launch.json:

```
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "Debug test",
            "type": "mono",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "test.exe",

            "type": "mono",
            "request": "attach",
            "address": "localhost",
            "port": 5858
        }
    ]
}
```

data.title: Navigate Soft Tabs As If They Are Hard Tabs
data.body:
If implemented properly, the user should not even realize they are working with spaces for indentation, which is one of the greatest pains of a person who prefers tabs for indentation working on a file that has spaces for indentation.
## Spaces should be treated as if they were tabs under the following conditions
1. The text editor's `insertSpaces` setting is `true` (or leading spaces precede tab characters on a line).
2. The cursor is within the range of leading indentation.
   1. We can't possibly guess where indentation ends and alignment begins, so this includes all leading whitespace (both spaces and tab characters, assuming each tab character is the width of `tabSize`).
3. The user attempts to do any of the following:
   1. Arrow-key navigation.
   2. Backspace.
   3. Delete.
   4. Mouse selections (more difficult to implement, I'm sure).
## Examples of how spaces are treated as tabs
1. If the cursor is at the beginning of the line and the right arrow key is pressed, the cursor jumps `tabSize` spaces, instead of just one.
2. If `tabSize` is `4` and the cursor is on position `6` (between tabs) and the left arrow key is pressed, the cursor jumps `2` spaces instead of `4`, landing gracefully on a tab stop.
3. If `tabSize` is `4` and the cursor is on position `4`, but the first non-whitespace character is on position `6`, then the space on position `5` is assumed to be alignment; thus, a right arrow key press would land on position `5`.
4. The backspace and delete keys should eliminate up to `tabSize` spaces in one batch, so that a single undo operation restores all of the spaces that were deleted.
5. Ideally, mouse selections would also be restricted to tab stops, so you can't individually select the spaces between a single indent.
## Exposing an editor setting
- Perhaps an editor setting called `navigateSoftTabsAsHard` should be exposed for those who wish to opt in or out of this feature. The default value is debatable.

data.title: Changing TextEditor.options issues
data.body:
We are working on the EditorConfig plugin and we have issues regarding `TextEditor.options`.

Users don't have to specify values for let's say `indent_style`. Let's take the following `.editorconfig`

``` ini
root = true

[*]
indent_style = tab

[{package.json,*.yml}]
indent_style = space
indent_size = 2
```

And my VSCode settings file looks like this

``` js
{
    "editor.insertSpaces": "auto",
    "editor.tabSize": "auto"
}
```

If I open `package.json`, the style should be set to `space` and the indent size to `2`. If I open `index.js`, it should set the `style` to `tab` and take the global setting (which is `auto`) so it should be calculated by VS Code itself. At the moment this is not possible. Because you have to overwrite the entire object which prevents auto-calculating the indent size.

@alexandrudima I think you are in charge for something like this :)?

data.title: [grammars] Pluggable syntax highlight engine for templating languages between backticks ``

To illustrate this, please [look at a followup which contains a screenshot](https://github.com/TypeStrong/atom-typescript/issues/800) ### The issue Since backticks `` are ment for template formats, it would be nice to have a way to define syntax highlighting between them. For example Angular2 implements templates in TypeScript as following: ``` typescript @Component({ selector: 'tabs', template: `
  • Tab 1
  • Tab 2
` }) ``` ### Atom ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/516972/12890361/95d640ba-ce83-11e5-8353-0d8fbf85baa7.png)

data.body:
### Assignments
- [x] Windows @stevencl 
- [x] OS X @weinand 
- [x] Linux @isidorn 
### Details

You can now quick open working files.
- verify the picker is well integrated into our quick open story and either shows you all working files or the ones matching your search if searching
- verify the order matches the order in the explorer unless you search, where we then use fuzzy matching/scoring
- verify you see untitled files as well as dirty indicators for dirty files

data.title: cannot remove breakpoint if breakpoint is on empty line
data.body:
When editing a file that has breakpoints, sometime I end up in a situation where the breakpoint sits on an empty line:

![2016-02-07 02-15-13](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/12888210/2297536e-ce79-11e5-976c-eb949cc5d859.png)

If this happens I'm no longer able to remove the breakpoint by clicking on it in the gutter.
I suggest that you allow to remove a breakpoint on any line.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Trying to exclude some directories from `workbench.action.quickOpen` but it doesn't seem to apply.

```
"files.exclude": {
    ".svn": true,
    "out/": true

```

It takes effect under SEARCH though.

data.title: Salsa doesn't support AMD and we should warn users that AMD is not supported
data.body: In the jsconfig.json we should emit a warning when a user configures the module type to be AMD, since Salsa does not support it.

data.title: Mac: wrong command shortcut for Hide Others
data.body:
The Mac OS X standard for "Hide Other Windows" is option-command-H.

![opt-cmd-h](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/114509/12882731/dc89ab44-ce53-11e5-9b44-2d599303819a.png)

In VS Code, that has been changed to shift-command-H.

![shift-cmd-h](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/114509/12882693/a541d03a-ce53-11e5-921c-c0b1d1049a60.png)

Perhaps there is some other command that maps to option-command-H by default? (I tried pressing the combo, but nothing happened.) In any case, this should be changed—violating this expectation is a big no-no.

data.title: Shared process died
data.body:
I don't know how but the shared process died. See stack traces below. This results in very wired behavior for:
- the currently opened rendered: all commands talking to the shared process end in endless progress (for example install extensions)
- a newly opened Windows shows quite some error messages all talking about the extension host not available. However the extension host dies because the shared process is not available

IMO we should have code that detects that the shared process went down and restart it.

data.title: [html] Add support for custom tag providers for HTML

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: It would be nice to have option to create custom tag providers for HTML as part of vs code extensions. For example, it'd allowed to implement Angular 2 or Ionic support in extension. Right now extensibility is limited to snippets which is nice but not enough.

data.title: LuaInterface support
data.body:
Hi all,

I'm looking for an editor/debugger (IDE) with all common features (color, auto completion, breakpoints, ...) to develop in LUA language under .NET plateform through LuaInterface library.
Would it be possible for VSCODE to do that easly?

Thanks in advance for your help.

data.title: Debug hover timeout should be the same as editor hover in general
data.body: I believe the debug hover is showing only after 1s of pause time whereas the normal editor hover appears much earlier (300ms?). I suggest to use exactly the same strategy to decide when to show the debug hover to make the behaviour consistent.

data.title: Replace-feature issues
data.body:
- tab moves cursor from the*\* text-to-find*\* box to the **replace-with-text** box, but shift-tab does _not_ move the mouse from the **replace-with-text** box back to the **text-to-find** box. 
- alt-A does not replace all-- you have to use the mouse (feel free to relocate this one to feature-requests).

data.title: Run normally without debug
data.body: Is there a command that will run my file without opening the debug console and without opening the debug tab?

data.title: Creating a file from Total Commander using VS Code as the editor can result in an hard-to-remove file
data.body:
Steps to reproduce:
1) set VS Code as the editor in Total Commander settings (use code.exe binary)
2) Shift+F4 in Total Commander to edit a new file. Use a filename WITHOUT extension (e.g. foo)
3) VS Code runs
4) save the file
5) for some reason VS Code creates two files (foo and foo.). The one ending with the dot is really hard to delete. Deletion using Windows Explorer, Total Commander, ... is not possible. The only way I could delete the file was through cmd.exe using foo~1 as the filename to delete.
